qas.question: Which book did Terry Eastland write?

answers.text: From Ending Affirmative Action: The Case for Colorblind Justice

qas.question: Outside of promoting diversity, was does Eastland believe the other reason to be in favor of affirmative action is?
What did Eastland believe the founders of affirmative action did not consider?

answers.text: how the benefits of affirmative action would go to those who did not need it

qas.question: Why does Sowell believe that there is little to no incentive for the preferred minority groups to perform at their best?
What argument does Sowell make in his claim that non - preferred minorities have less incentive to perform at their best?

plausible_answers.text: From Ending Affirmative Action: The Case for Colorblind Justice

qas.question: Which song did Terry Eastland write?
Outside of promoting diversity, was does Eastland believe the other reason to be against affirmative action is?

plausible_answers.text: how the benefits of affirmative action would go to those who did not need it, mostly middle class minorities

qas.question: What did Westland believe the founders of affirmative action did not consider?
Why does Sowell believe that there is a lot of incentive for the preferred minority groups to perform at their best?
What argument does Sowell make in his claim that preferred minorities have less incentive to perform at their best?

context: Terry Eastland, the author who wrote <a0_0><b5_0>From Ending Affirmative Action: The Case for Colorblind Justice<b5_0/><a0_0/> states, "Most arguments for affirmative action fall into two categories: <a1_0><b6_0>remedying past discrimination<b6_0/><a1_0/> and promoting diversity". Eastland believes that the founders of affirmative action did not anticipate <a2_0><b7_0>how the benefits of affirmative action would go to those who did not need it<a2_0/>, mostly middle class minorities<b7_0/>. Additionally, she argues that affirmative action carries with it a stigma that can create feelings of self-doubt and entitlement in minorities. Eastland believes that affirmative action is a great risk that only sometimes pays off, and that without it we would be able to compete more freely with one another. Libertarian economist Thomas Sowell identified what he says are negative results of affirmative action in his book, Affirmative Action Around the World: An Empirical Study. Sowell writes that affirmative action policies encourage non-preferred groups to designate themselves as members of preferred groups [i.e., primary beneficiaries of affirmative action] to take advantage of group preference policies; that they tend to benefit primarily the most fortunate among the preferred group (e.g., upper and middle class blacks), often to the detriment of the least fortunate among the non-preferred groups (e.g., poor white or Asian); that they reduce the incentives of both the preferred and non-preferred to perform at their best – the former <a3_0><b8_0>because doing so is unnecessary<b8_0/><a3_0/> and the latter <a4_0>because <b9_0>it can prove futile<b9_0/><a4_0/> – thereby resulting in net losses for society as a whole; and that they engender animosity toward preferred groups as well.:115–147
